chunk:
event name: droid trooper, club: robolution, category: flagship, points: 300, 200, 150, faculty advisor: 
dr. binay kumar, timing: round 1: 9 am - 11:30 am, round 2: 12 pm - 3 pm, venue: ic arena, description: 
"droid troopers" is an exciting fun robotics competition with a set of challenging tasks. the students + 
participating robots  are required to  adhere to specific specifications, including motor type,  torque, 
battery voltage, and wheel size. the competition features a dynamic track with various obstacles, such 
as cones, ramps, pneumatic rods, and more. in round 1, robots must navigate the obstacles efficiently, 
with the option to resume from checkpoints. top-performing teams advance to round 2, where they must 
strategically place cubes in designated locations while overcoming obstacles. skipping obstacles incurs 
time  penalties.  rules  &  regulations:  team  size:  1-4  bot  specifications:  dimensions:  30  x  30  cm, 
mechanical arm or gripper: movable/non-movable, motor: 100 - 300 rpm, torque:less than 5 kg-cm, 
battery: 12 v, wheels: 10 cm (max. diameter), bot can be wire or wireless, it can be fully or partially 
autonomous or manually, the track shown in the diagram is for reference only; it may change to some 
extent. track specifications: track breadth: 60 cm, obstacles: zone 2: cone is placed in a random position. 
cone dimension: height- 6.5 cm radius: 4 cm, zone 3: ramp dimension - 30 x 30 cm and angle: 45 degree, 
pneumatics rod(if you choose zone 3(a)i.e. elevated zone(height = 30 cm)) or fan(if you choose zone 
3(b)), zone 4: speed breaker - shape: equilateral triangular of base 5 cm, zone 5: slippery zone, zone 6: 
a track full of graves, zone 7: a ramp at 30 degree and road that will be split in two. there will be one 
checkpoint-3.  if  you  fall  down  after  that  checkpoint,  you  can  resume  from  that  checkpoint.  cube 
dimension: 8 cm x 8 cm x 8 cm, black spot dimension (where in round 2 the cube is need to place): 10 
cm x 10cm. the event is divided into two rounds: round 1: the bot need to clear all the obstacle that is 
coming in between of it passage as fast as it could. top teams will get chance to play the next round. if 
the bot failed to avoid the obstacle, it can resume from the last checkpoint it had clear. every team will 
get three chance to clear down the obstacles. if it failed then the bot need to skip that barrier. in second 
obstacle, there will be two choice given to each team, either they climb and clear down the pneumatic 
rod or clear down the fan. if the respective team are not able to clear down the pneumatic rod then they 
need to go from below of it. if they failed to clear down the fan, then they need to skip the whole 
obstacle. round 2: the top teams now have to clear down all the obstacles by placing cubes from one 
point to another at different locations as fast as possible. the cube should be properly placed in the 
location or in the black mark. if it is placed then only the robot is allowed to move ahead. the bot need 
to climb the ramp compulsory. there will be no choice given to the team as they were given earlier. the 
bot need to traverse in blue region only. every team will have two choices: either they can clear the 
obstacle, or they can skip the obstacle. if they skip the obstacles, it will lead to a deduction of 50 points. 
an autonomous bot will only be awarded points in the autonomous section if it clears the zone in 
autonomous mode; if the bot is manually controlled, it will be marked with the points of the manual 
section. contact: arnav roy – 9142862795

event name: chem-e-cipher, club: iiche, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. abhijit 
mondal, timing:  round  1: 9.00 am - 10:00 pm, round 2:  10.30 am - 12:00 pm,  venue: classroom, 
description:  "chem_e_cipher"  is  a  technical  competition  that  merges  fundamental  knowledge  of 
chemistry and physics with proficient coding skills. the event aims to foster a synergy between these 
two domains, recognizing their growing interconnection in the modern world. in the initial round, 
participants will be presented with a complex problem statement sourced from the subject of physics 
and chemistry basically of classes11 and 12th. their task will involve conceiving innovative solutions 
to address the challenges posed by the given scenario. submissions will be evaluated based on the 
feasibility,  creativity,  and practicality  of  the  proposed  ideas.  those  with  outstanding  concepts  will 
advance to the subsequent round. in the final round, participants will face the same problem statement, 
but the challenge will escalate. this time, they are required to translate the problem into code, visuals, 
or predictions utilizing their programming prowess, data analytics expertise, and machine learning 
modelling  skills.  the  objective  is  to  devise  a  comprehensive  solution  that  not  only  encompasses 
optimized coding practices but also showcases the functional and predictive aspects of the solution. at 
the conclusion of the event, positions will be awarded with the recognition of the most exceptional 
solutions. a panel of judges, well-versed in the core principles of chemical engineering will oversee the 
evaluation process. additionally, efforts will be made to include a judge from the computer science, 
information  technology,  artificial  intelligence,  or  machine  learning  field,  further  emphasizing  the 

interdisciplinary nature of the event. this diverse panel of judges ensures a comprehensive assessment, 
incorporating both the chemical engineering and technological facets of the participants' submissions. 
rules & regulations: round 1 (i) the first round would be a general quiz with basic physics chemistry 
and aptitude based questions with some connections to chemical engineering the team who solves the 
maximum question will qualify to the second round. (ii) use of phones and other electronic gadgets are 
not allowed. (iii)only 2 members are allowed to give the quiz in round 1 round 2. (i) participants will 
be presented with a complex problem statement sourced from the subject of physics and chemistry 
basically of classes 11 and 12th. (ii) participants are required to translate the problem into code, visuals, 
or predictions utilizing their programming skills using their personal laptops on a coding platform. 
(iii)positions will be awarded with the recognition of the most exceptional solutions. resources: paper, 
pen contact: rahul kumar suman (7209612453)

event name: murder mystery, club: leo, category: formal, points: 120, 100, 80, faculty advisor: dr. amit 
saran, timing: 9:00 am - 3:00 pm, venue: mehak, description: prepare for the return of the year's most 
thrilling adventure, "murder mystery 2023," organised by the leoclub! following its record-breaking 
participation last year, the challenging contest of the town's sherlocks is back, now grander and even 
more  enigmatic.  collaborate  with  your  team  of  3-4  detectives  to  decipher  intricate  clues,  explore 
concealed locations, and unveil the ultimate enigma. anticipate heart-pounding excitement, unforeseen 
twists, and the opportunity to become pantheon's ultimate sleuths.solve the final mystery and lay claim 
to your fame and glory in this epic quest. don't miss your chance for greatness – "murder mystery 2023" 
awaits! rules & regulations: 1. teams should consist of 3-4 members and each team shouldselect a team 
leader with whom the further communication shall be done. 2. do carry your id cards for verification 
before the start of the event. 3. participants are expectedto go through the rule book properlyand respect 
all laws and regulations throughout the event. 4. all participant teams are expectedto maintain good 
sportsmanship and fair play throughout the event. 5. all teams are expected to treat the organisers with 
respect, and wait for their turns at the locations for the clues. they shall be provided on a first come first 
serve basis. 6. in case of any conflict or issues, the decision of leo club will be considered finaland 
abiding. resources: 1. stationary 2. 6 a4 packets 3. 3 pen packets 4. water bottles 5. refreshments 6. table 
chairs at each location contact: 1. neetu kumari - 6203535974

event name: anvil, club: sime, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. l. n. pattanaik, 
timing: round 1 - 9 am - 11 am, round 2 - 11:30 am -1:30 pm, venue: classrooms- 2, description: join 
us for the ultimate intellectual showdown at the anvil challenge! this thrilling competition is open to 
individuals seeking to prove their prowess in a battle of wits. the anvil challenge spans four exhilarating 
levels, each designed to test your knowledge, problem-solving skills, and quick thinking. here's what 
you can expect.the competition consists of 2 round containing generalquiz in round 1 and a energetic 
event containing four levels:level 1, level2, level 3, and level4 in round 2.this round 2 consists industrial 
and technical  questions. with a unique twist, the difficulty of questions increases  with each level, 
offering a balanced challenge for all participants. the top 3 participants withthe highest cumulative 
scores across all four levels will claim victory.in the event of both points and time ties, joint winners 
will be declared. gear up for a thrilling journey through knowledge, strategy, and quick reflexes as you 
aim to become one of the anvil challenge's triumphant champions! gear up for a thrilling journey 
through knowledge, strategy, and quick reflexes as you aim to become one of the anvil challenge's 
triumphant champions! rules & regulations: 1. participating team need to take part in event in the team 
of 2. 2. top 10 teams will be promoted for 2nd round after a general quiz in round 1. 3. in 2nd round 
your performance at each level carries a different weightage – 10%, 20%, 30%, and 40% respectively 
for levels 1 through 4. 4. the timestamp of your answers will be recorded, serving as the tiebreaker in 
case of a points tie. resources: 1. pen( 20 packs) 2. white sheets(1 bundle) contact: 1. aman kumar – 
6204056473

event name: aeromodelling, club: aerospace, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. 
priyank kumar, timing: round 1 - 11:30 am to 1.30 pm, round 2 - 1.30 pm to 2.30 pm, venue: classroom, 
description and rules: prepareto soar to new heightswith our thrilling aeromodelling contest, a highlight 
of our college's upcoming technical fest. this event is designed to test your knowledge and hands-on 

skills in the exciting world of aeromodelling, all while promoting creativity, engineering prowess,and 
aviation  enthusiasm.  round  1:  prelims&  quiz  in  the  first  round,  participants  will  engage  in  an 
exhilarating quiz competition that will challenge their knowledge of aerodynamics, aviation history, 
and aircraft design. only the sharpest minds and aviation enthusiasts will make it to the next stage. this 
round will not only test your bookish knowledge but also ignite your passion for flight. round 2: final 
modelling round the finalists will put their knowledge to practical use in the second round, where they'll 
design and construct aeromodels using versatile teflon sheets. this round promises hands-on excitement 
as participants showcase their engineering and craftsmanship skills. their creations will be judged based 
on various criteria, including flight distance, accuracy, and design innovation. resources: 1. teflon sheets 
2. scissors 3. cello tapes 4. fevicol 5. stapler 6. pen 7. paper contact: priyanshu kumar - 6203551107

event name: connect-o-thon, club: iete, category: formal, points: 120, 100, 80, faculty advisor: dr. g.s. 
gupta, timing: round 1: 11.30 - 12.30 pm, round 2: 1:30 pm - 3:30 pm, venue: round 1 - seminar hall 1/ 
g2/g3,  round  2  -  rnd lab,  description:  get  your  team  ready  for  connect-o-thon,  where  knowledge, 
teamwork, and assembly skills will be put to the test!. hosted by iete, where teams will test their 
knowledge and assembly skills in a thrilling competition. the event consists of two parts: a quiz and a 
pc assembly challenge. here's how it works: rules & regulations: 1. team composition: - each team can 
have up to 3 members. 2. event format: - part 1: quiz (35 minutes) - part 2: pc assembly challenge 3. 
quiz details: - there will be 5 selected teams. - teams will answer questions in a quiz format within 35 
minutes. - correct answers earn teams the right to receive pc assembly parts. 4. pc assembly challenge: 
- teams receive disassembled pcs. - members must switch places every 15 minutes. - pc parts will be 
provided  to  teams  one  by  one  every  10  minutes  if  they  answer  quiz  questions  correctly.  5. 
communication: - no communication with outsiders during the event. 6. scoring: - quiz questions and 
pc assembly performance will determine team scores. 7. time calculation: - the time taken for the 
assembly challenge will be part of the scoring. resources: - 5 computers - 5 screwdriver sets - a4 size 
papers - 5 thermal pastes contact: 1.arya shreshth: 9934086247 2. amitesh kumar sinha : 8409742400

event name: bot soccer, club: eee society, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. s 
shiva kumar, timing: round 1 - 11:30 am - 2:30 pm (round 2 on 3rd day of pantheon), venue: classroom, 
description: “i love football, and you love football, and arguing about it is just a waste of time.” ~ ian 
slatter  the  event  in  question,  as  the  name  implies,  centresaround  robotic  entities  crafted  by  the 
contestants themselves, which will subsequently engage in a soccer match. this event is structured into 
three distinct rounds. in the initial round, known as round 1, sixteen teams will be chosen througha 
knockout-style  video  game  competition  among  which  8  teams  will  be  chosen  to  advanceto  the 
subsequent round  on the basis  of  ppt  they  give  on how  to  make the  bot.  moving  on  to round  2, 
participants will be tasked with constructing their own robotic systems. each participating team will be 
allocated a total of nine hours to develop their bots. the requisite equipmentand technical supportwill 
be provided by the organising society. the culmination of the event will occur in the final round, wherein 
these bots will face off in a competitive soccer match. brace yourselves for a voyage laden with intricate 
intricacies and unforeseen challenges. rules & regulations: 1. the event will have team participation [1-
3 members]. 2. those teams who fail to develop a bot in round 2 would be eliminated. 3. teams who win 
the final will win. resources: 1. room permission 2. components for bots:- ● robo kit ● nodemcu ● 
motor  controller  ●  jumper  wires  ●  battery  ●  charger  3.  refreshments  contact:  1.  avinash  kumar- 
9471308901 2. akshay tripathi- 9799042593

event name: tower of paper, club: ces, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. mani 
mohan, timing: 11:30 am - 1:30 pm, venue: classroom, description: this event consists of one stage: 
● 
the result for the stage will be according to the length of the tower created using newspaper, in case of 
a draw  the  strength  will  be  considered.  ●  the results  will  be published  on  the same  day.  rules  & 
regulations: 1. participants must register before or during the event. 2. the teams will be given 15 
minutes each 3. a team should consist of max 3 members. 4. the resources will be provided during the 
event. resources: 1. newspapers - 15 kg 2. adhesives - fevicol (30 bottles) 3. scissors - 10 contact: shreya 
sinha: 8709566909

event name: a book, a minute, club: the literary society, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty 

advisor: dr. niraj kumar singh, timing: 11:30 am - 1:30 pm, venue: classroom, description: a book,a 
minute is centred around the art of delivering a concise book synopsis within a 60-second timeframe. 
contestants will select a book of their choice and meticulously craft a script aimed at enthralling a panel 
of judges. the primary objective is to pique the judges' interest through a succinct yet compelling 
overview  of  the  chosen  book's  plot,  prompting  a  desire  to  buy  the  book.  rules  &  regulations:  1. 
contestants have to choose any novel or book that they have read and come prepared with a short script 
to explain the plot. 2. the objective of this oral presentation is to intrigue the judges and prompt them to 
buy the book 3. in addition to the oral presentations, participants will be required to submit a written 
version of their script for comprehensive evaluation. 4. speaking time is 1 minute. 5. both hindi and 
english entries are allowed resources: pen = 30 sheets= 50 posters= 20 water bottles four fiction books 
for two winners and two runner ups (rs.1500) contact: 1. lily - 6204489339

event name: the marketeers, club: edc, category: formal, points: 120, 100, 80, faculty advisor: mr. vishal 
h shah, timing: 11:30 am - 3:30 pm, venue: online platform, description: an event aimedat showcasing 
participants' analytical abilities and their utilization for businesses will be conducted. participants will 
receive a csv file, which they must analyze and devise both descriptive and prescriptive solutions 
tailored to a specific business scenario. the competition will consist of two rounds: the first round will 
be a quiz, and the second round will be the finale. the participant who presents the most outstanding 
solution,  evaluated  by  both  academic  and  industry  experts,  will  be  declared  the  winner  of  the 
competition.  rules  &  regulations:  the  event  organisers  reserve  the  rightto  make  rule  changes  or 
modifications in adverse conditions. any such changes will be communicated to participants as promptly 
as possible and will be made to ensure the fairness and integrity of the event. team size : 1-2 resources: 
no resources required contact: 1. ujjwal aman - 9508386750

event name: electroquest, club: ecesoc, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. s.s. 
tripathy,  timing:  round  1:  12.00  pm  -  2:00  pm,  round  2:  2.30  pm  -  4:30  pm,  venue:  classroom, 
description & rules: 1. round 1 : in this round teams will be shown some general science and tech related 
questions and answers that need to be marked by the teams on their laptops on a website which will be 
showing their live leaderboard. this round is a time game for all teams, faster ones will win. 2. round 2 
: top 8 qualifying teams will be given some electronics related coding questions. these questions are 
based on simple electronics and general science knowledge and code to be written is just some basic 
coding skills. major catch is the electronics and science knowledge.this round will be held on hackerrank 
platform. 3. important instruction : teams need to bring their own laptops and team size 1-2. resources: 
1. posters 2. flex 3. volunteer id cards 4. round 1 - paper,pen, tape, scissors 5. round 2 - paper, pen 
contact: 1. chhavi rani: 8340319623 2. nikhil verma: 9660673731

event name: what if, club: unesquo, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. s.k. 
mishra,  timing:  1:00  pm  -  3:30  pm,  venue:  classroom,  description:  step  into  a  world  where  the 
boundaries of reality blur, and the possibilities are limitless. "what if" is an extraordinary event that 
transcends the ordinary and invites you to explore the realms of imagination, curiosity, and creativity. 
this one-of-a-kind experience is designed to inspire, challenge, and amaze, leaving you with a sense of 
wonder  and  the  question,  "what  if  anything  is  possible?"  individual  participation  event  where 
participants  will  be  given  historical  or fantasy  situations  where  they  would  have to  explain  in  an 
elocution if there was a different situation rather than the actual true situation. rules & regulations: 4. 
the event will have individual participation. 5. participants will be given historical or fantasy situations 
through chits. they will have to prepare in 5 minutes and then deliver a speech. they would have to 
explain in an elocution if there was a different situation rather than the actual true situation. 6. each 
speaker will be given a total time of 3 minutes to deliver the speech. 7. the participants will be marked 
on creativity, confidence, style, impact & speech delivery. resources: 1. a4 sheets - 10 2. pens - 5 
contact: 1. chhavi rani: 8340319623 2. nikhil verma: 9660673731

event name: shutter ascent, club: psoc, category: formal, points: 120, 100, 80, faculty advisor: dr. 
priyank saxena, timing: round 1 - 1.00 pm - 3.30 pm (round 2 on 2nd day of the pantheon), venue: lh - 
2, description: this event will unfold in two captivating rounds, where the most exceptional individuals 
will advance to round 2 to vie for the coveted title of "best creative portrait photographer." rules & 

regulations: 1. any device can be used for clicking the pictures 2. participants will be alloweda total 
time of 6 hours to get the pictures 3. at the end of 6 hours, participants are to submit their entries(only 
minimal editingis allowed, no image manipulation is allowed) 4. creative entries will be given more 
points 5. entries deemed offensive, obscene or vulgarwould be disqualified immediately round 2 : 1. 
participants will be alloweda total time of two hours to get the pictures ( round 2) 2. at the end of 2 
hours, participants are to submit their entries(only minimal editingis allowed, no image manipulation is 
allowed) resources: 1. projector 2. reflectors 3. diffusers 4. stands contact: 1. amiya jha - 7979077549

event name: google it out, club: iet, category: informal, points: 50, 40, 30, faculty advisor: dr. d. k. 
updhayay, timing: round 1 - 1:30 am - 2:30 am round 2 - 2:30 am - 3:30 pm venue: rnd, description: the 
contestants will be shown multipleimages and will be requiredto extract similarimages in google image 
results by tweaking the search parameters. teams would be ranked on the basis of images identified in 
the given time. rules & regulations: team size: 2-3 1. use of image searching tools(like google lens)is 
strictly prohibited. 2. the participants are required to carry out the competition in an incognito window 
to removeimpact of prior search results. 3. in a situation where the teamsare tied on the basisof points a 
tie breakerround would be conducted, where the fastest team to solve will win the round. 4. teams would 
be ranked on the basis of numberof images identified. resources: 1. 2 large rooms with projector access 
contact: 1. shubhankar dubey - 7004591798

event name: unleashing minds: solving the enigma, club: 180dc's, category: , points: , faculty advisor: 
dr. supriyo roy, timing: round 1: 5th october round 2: 8th october, (4:00-6:30 pm), venue: round 1: 
online round 2: seminar room hybrid mode, description: unleashing minds: solving the enigma." this 
innovative  event  combines  the  thrill  of  a  mind-boggling  puzzle  with  the  analytical  powerof  data 
manipulation using excel, r, sql, and power bi. designed to challenge and stimulate participants, "solving 
the enigma" promises an unforgettable experience. assembling a diversegroup of aspiring strategists, 
analysts,  and  problem-solvers,  the  event  invitesthem  to  collaborate  and  showcase  theiranalytical 
prowess. the centerpiece is a large,intriguing dataset that holds the key to unlocking a hidden message—
a puzzle that demands skill, teamwork, and strategic thinking. . rules & regulations: 1. registration till 
4th october 2. all the quizzes and puzzle-solving must be completed by team membersonly. 3. teams 
are expected to conduct any and all necessary research through publicly available resources. resources: 
1. lab-4 in rnd 2. whiteboard-1 3. whiteboard markers- red, blue 4. prints-rulebook, team tags, team info 
5. pens-5 6. notepads-5 7. refreshments contact: mayank sinha 8080819105 saurav 8210819135

event name: xerolag, club: sports and adventure club, category: formal, points: 120, 100, 80, faculty 
advisor: dr. s.k singh, timing: 8:00 pm - 12:00 pm (next day), venue: rnd lab-4, description: all enrolled 
teams are invited for a 5v5 preliminary group stage wherein the rounds will be eliminatory in nature. 
teamsadvancing from the group stageswill compete in the semi-finals and the grand finals where 3 
matches on different maps will be held. a team will be eliminated after a three match spell. use of any 
unfair means will result in completedisqualification. participants are required to bring their own pcs, 
mouse and other peripherals. rules & regulations: 1. map pool:to be declared 2. map will be decided by 
the team captains by consensus or a veto. 3. timeout is already available in game(60 s each, 1 per half 
per team). 4.  in case of dc/technical  problem 5 mins pause timer  will  be available  only  once per 
game.post 5 mins, the match will resume with the player disconnected. incase of disconnection the 
second time, no timer would be available and the game would resume. 5. in case of discrepancy in result 
contact admins 6. team size : 5 players and 1 substitute resources: 1. lab-4 in rnd 2. whiteboard-1 3. 
whiteboard  markers-  red, blue  4.  prints-rulebook,  team  tags,  team  info  5.  pens-5  6.  notepads-5  7. 
refreshments contact: yashdev tiwari- 6393115243 kartik doley- 8169217376 piyush raj- 9939175648

event name: the pantheon quiz, club: unesquo + events, category: flagship, points: 1. 300, 2. 200, 3. 
150, timing: round 1: 12:30 pm - 1:15 pm, round 2: 1:30 pm - 3:30 pm, faculty advisor: dr. s.k. mishra, 
venue: cat hall, description: embark on a thrilling intellectual adventure with the pantheon quiz. this 
quiz spans multiple dimensions - science, technology, business acumen and much more - to test your 
knowledge and expand your horizons. dive into scientific mysteries, explore technological frontiers, 
tackle brain-teasing puzzles, and navigate real-world business scenarios. each questiontakes you deeper 
into the realms of discovery, allowingyou to accumulate points and compete with fellow knowledge 

enthusiasts.  join  us  for  an  exhilarating  journey  and  unleash  the  power  of  your  multidimensional 
intelligence! rules & regulations: the event will have team participation [1-3 members]. round 1 will be 
a pen & paper round. round 2 will be a verbal round on the stage with top 6 teams. resources: a4 sheets 
-  200  pens  -  100  projector  pa  system  contact:  kr.  harshwardhan:  9142821947  akshay  tripathi: 
9799042593

event name: capture the flag, club: ieee, category: formal, points: 1. 120, 2. 100, 3. 80, faculty advisor: 
dr. aftab alam, timing: 8.00 am to 4.00 pm next day, venue: online, description: 36 hrs long event in 
which participants attempt to find text strings,called "flags", which are secretly hidden in purposefully-
vulnerable programsor websites. therewill be multiple challenges with some points. rules & regulations: 
1. ctf will be an online event lasting 36 hours. 2. each team can have a maximum of 3 members. 3. every 
challenge will have certain points that will decrease over time. 4. after the event ends, the team with the 
maximum points will win. 5. collaboration or communication with members of other teams during the 
competition is not allowed. resources: 1. money for hosting website of ctf: ₹7000 2. access to college's 
dc++ server 3. prize money ₹15000 contact: prateek krishna – 8210371121

event name: asta di autos, club: srijan + sime, category: formal, points: 1. 120, 2. 100, 3. 80, faculty 
advisor: dr. somak dutta, timing: round 1- 9.00 am - 11.30am round 2- 12.00 pm - 2.00 pm, venue: lh 
1, description: "asta di autos" is an exhilarating event, where the registered teams will participate in a 
test based on aptitude and formula 1 automobile-related questions. in the first round, teams have to 
showcase their knowledge and skills, striving to secure a spot in the next stage. the top 6 teams will be 
selected to advance to the second round. in the second round, the auction round, the selected teams will 
be provided with a specific budget. they will engage in strategic bidding to acquire various segments of 
a car, including chassis, brakes, wheels, engines, and transmission. this round demands a comprehensive 
understanding of automobile engineering, as well as shrewdness and calculated decision-making. rules 
& regulations: team size must be 1-3 members resources: papers pens posters flex volunteers id cards 
contact: ayush kumar: 8102708909

event name: volt racer : the electronic carnage, club: ecesoc, category: informal, points: 1. 50, 2. 40, 3. 
30, faculty advisor: dr. s s tripathy, timing: round 1 - 9:00-11:00 round 2 - 1:30-3:00, venue: round 1 - 
classroom  round  2  -  classroom,  description  &rules:  round  1:  in  the  first  round  all  teams  will  be 
answering  a  logical  reasoning  test  in  pen  paper  format.  this  round  will  consist  of  20  reasoning 
questionsbased on the basic science domain. it will be a mind game in which answers are electronics 
related and very near to the questions shown. round 2 : top 8 teams will be qualified for round 2. here, 
teams will be asked to play smash karts in the room created by us and the top teams will be asked simple 
electronics related questions and points will be provided accordingly. if a team fails to answer the 
question then it will be passed according to the ranking in the game and points will be provided after 
some deductions. important instruction : teams need to bring their own laptops and team size 1-2. 
resources: posters flex volunteer id cards round 1 - paper scissors paper pen contact: harsh verma - 
9031538883

event name: musical charades, club: spic macay, category: informal, points: 1. 50, 2. 40, 3. 30, faculty 
advisor: dr. mrinal pathake, timing: 9 am - 12 pm, venue: classroom, description: get ready to elevate 
the classic game of charades to a whole new level with "musical charades!" this uproarious event adds 
a thrilling twist to the beloved game of gestures and clues. here's how it works: teams of enthusiastic 
participants will don noise-cancelling headphones blastingenergetic tunes, making communication a 
hilarious challenge. as you take turns acting out movie titles, book names, famous phrases, and more, 
your teammates will attempt to decipher your messages without the aid of spoken words. the result? a 
raucously entertaining evening filled with laughter, wild gesticulations, and the delightful chaos of

event name – wiki wars, club – biots, category: informal, points: 1. 50, 2. 40, 3. 30, faculty advisor: dr. 
dinesh prasad, timings:, venue: rnd lab, description & rules: wiki wars is a skillfuland smart game of 
navigating through several pages of wikipediaon a desktop without the use of a keyboard. it involves 

reaching the target wikipedia page from an already given wikipedia page in the limited time and with 
the least number of clicks. players use the blue wikipedia links to go from one page to another. the 
number of players for the game is 2. wiki wars will be conductedin three mega rounds- round1 – the 
round 1 is indeed the simplest.players just need to navigatethrough pages using wiki links to reach the 
desired wikipedia page. the top teams qualify for the next round. round2 – the round 2 will be a test of 
your creativity and intellect. playerswill be given a clue or a storyline based on whichthey need to 
navigate betweenwiki pages and reach the final wiki page. a certain percentage of top teams will make 
it to the 3rd and final round. round3 – the 3rd and the final round will be a test of your patienceand 
compatibility with your fellow teammates. one player has to act out the word to be clickedand the 
otherwill guess the word and click on it to proceed further to reach the final wikipedia page. if the other 
player is unable to guess the exact word then a chance will be given to draw a related picture of the 
word. although drawing a related picture will lead to negative marking. resources: paper pens contact: 
aditi singh: 7061767535 chinmay patade : 9137213409

event name: air crash investigation, club: aerosoc, category: formal, points: 1. 120, 2. 100, 3. 80, faculty 
advisor: dr. priyank kumar, timing: round 1 - 11:30 am to 12.00 pm round 2 - 12:30 pm to 2 pm, venue: 
classroom, description: the safest mode of transportation but one small mistake and it becomes the 
deadliest accident. "examine the wrecks and official records, and hear from eyewitnesses, passengers, 
and aviation experts as we reconstruct some of the most tragic disasters in aviation history.air crash 
investigation examines what went wrong and how future disasters can be averted." be an air crash 
investigator and, with your friends, solve real-life inspiredair crashes just like a real one with the black 
box data, flight path, pilot's history, recordings and much more in your hands. rules & regulations: 
thiswill consist of two rounds: round 1: 
● teams will have to appear for an easy test to prove their 
efficiency as air crash investigators. ● only the top 15 teams will be promotedto the post of air crash 

investigator and will solveone of the most complicated cases ever in the history of the airline. round 2: 
in round 2, teamswill have to grab theirproofs and all the data regarding that crash throughriddles. since, 
in an investigation, the order in which you gather all the proofs matter, points will be awarded in that 
order. we will provide all the riddlesto the teams at once,and teams will get the related fightdata by 
solving thoseriddles. there will be a time limitto solve the case, afterwhich the teamswill be disqualified 
as an investigator. the data will include the following: ● black box recording in printed form. ● flight 
path data with required fuel and actualfuel used. ● pilot's medical history. the data will contain all basic 
procedures followed during takeoff and landing. so, the investigators must know the fundamentals. a 
visualized  video  of  the  crash  will  also  be  provided  to  some  teams  as  a  bonus  according  to  their 
gameplay. resources: teflon sheets scissors cello tapes fevicol stapler pen paper contact: deewakar 
prasad - 9470102532

event name: robo rumble, club: robolution, category: formal, points: 1. 120, 2. 100, 3. 80, faculty 
advisor: dr. binay kumar, timing: round 1 : 11.00am-1.00pm round 2: 1.30-3.30pm, venue: shorbagh, 
description: robo rumble is a fast-paced and action-packed roboticsevent where teams of 1 to 4 members 
will pit their robotic creations against each other. the primary objective is to outmanoeuvre and outlast 
the competition, with the last robot standing declared the winner. the competition takes place in a 2m x 
2m arena, which poses challenges such as a central pit with a 50 cm diameter, and four formidable 
rotating rods at the corners. the pit and the rods are designed to disqualify robots that fall into them or 
are thrown out of the arena. rules & regulations: 1. arena specifications: (i) arena dimensions: 2m x 2m 
(ii) central pit: in the centreof the arena, there's a 50 cm radius pit. any robotthat falls into the pit will 
be disqualified. (iii) rotating rods: four 60 cm rotating rods are placedat the corners of the arena. two 
rods rotate horizontally, and two rotate vertically, aiming to throw robots out of the arena.1. robot 
specifications: ● size constraint: robots must adhere to a 30cm x 30cm size constraint. ● weight limit: 
robots shouldweigh not more than 2.5 kg. ● no mounted weapon systems: robotsare not allowedto have 
any  mounted  weapon  systems,  including  hydraulic  arms,  flames,  solid  objects,  liquids,rollers,  or 
spinners. combat techniques must rely solely on the robot's structure. ● motors: motors used should not 
exceed 300 rpm, and the torque must be less than 5 kg-cm. ● battery: the battery voltageshould not 
exceed12.6 volts. 
● wheels: the maximum diameterof the wheels should be 10 cm. ● drivetrain: any 
drivetrain configuration is allowed. 
● robots can 
be eitherwired or remote-controlled. 
● innovative 
combat techniques: teams can implement various innovative combat techniques, but these should be 
based on the robot's structure, such as a pointed, sharpened, sawtooth, streamlined design, a wedge, or 
a round structure. it means only structural discretion is allowed. mounted weapons systems are not 
allowed. and in any case any structural outgrowth must be within the size constraints. 2. start: all the 
bots will start simultaneously from the cross marked area. 3. engagement time:robots are prohibited 
from remaining idle for more than 20 seconds. they must engage with one of the other robots during 
this time. 4. disqualification: a robot will be disqualified if it fallsinto the centralpit or is thrown out of 
the arena by the rotating rods, another bot or any other means. the robot will also be disqualified if it 
remains  idle  for  more  than  20  seconds  withoutengaging  with  any  other  bot.  5.  to  be  considered 
disqualified, the robot must fully fall out of the arena. if any part of the robot is insidethe arena it will 
be considered eligiblefor the fightuntil it is thrown out fully by another robot or 50 percent of the bot is 
outside the arena for more than 30 seconds. 6. if 50 percent of the bot is outside the arena or in the 
central pit, the team will be given a warning. if in the next 30 seconds,the bot doesn’t climb fully inside 
the arena, they will be considered disqualified. 7. the last robot standingon the arena will be adjudged 
the  winner.  the  runners  up  team  might  or  might  not  be  considered  depending  on  the  number  of 
participants. 8. 2-4 bots can fight in one round depending on the numberof participants. resources: 1. 
wooden ply- 1 (expected) rs. 1500 2. dc motors (300 rpm) 200 x 12pc =rs 2400 (3 teams) 3. motor 
driver l293d x 3 piece :rs 180 contact: 1. navneet kumar - 8002781431 2. dikshant vats - 8340669766

event name: buggy escape, club: team aveon, category: informal, points: 1. 50, 2. 40, 3. 30, faculty 
advisor: dr. s. s. tripathi, timing: round 1 - 11:30 am - 12:30 pm round 2 - 12:30pm - 2:00pm, venue: 
round 1: classroom round 2: in front of prod. dept, description: so, whats the hurry? yes the time is less 
and you have to keep it lesser still. aveon participates in the sae e-baja event every year and one of the 
key tests in the event involves escapingout of the atv under 5 seconds. we intend to bring adrenaline to 
our campus and challenge you the same. it's not tough as it sounds, right? then come on and get locked, 
let's see how fast you can unlock yourself! rules & regulations: round 1 thisis basic a test on cars and 
electric vehicles. round 2 is where the top contestants advance. round 2 1. it is an individual event. 2. 
participants will be restrained to the vehicle.the winner is the competitor who frees themselves and exits 
the atv in the shortest amount of time. 3. each person will have two chances.the fastest betweenthe two 
will be chosen. 4. the chance is nullified if any participant's body part makestouch with the atv in any 
way. resources: 1. baja escape - stationary 2. arm restraint 3. neck support contact: ayush kumar - 79923 
31764

event name: css battle, club: ieee, category: formal, points: 1. 120, 2. 100, 3. 80, faculty advisor: dr. 
aftab alam, timing: round 1 - 11:30 am - 12:30 pm round 2 - 12:30pm - 2:30pm, venue: round 1: 
classrooms - 3 round 2; classroom- 1, description: this event consists of 2 rounds both round will be 
conducted offline. the first round will be the elimination round and 12-15 teams will qualifyfor second 
round. in second round qualifiedteams will be shown some design on projectorand they have to clone 
that design using css. team that is closest to design wins. a team can have maximum 2 members in both 
rounds. rules & regulations: - css battle will consist of 2 rounds. - each team can have a maximum of 
two participants. - 1st round will be a quiz round. -in 2nd round teams will be providedwith a design 
prototype and a code snippet that they must implement using html and css only. -teamsmust use html 
and css exclusively for coding; externallibraries or languages are not allowed. -the scoring criteriafor 
round 2 will be based on accuracy, code quality, and creativity. -in case of a tie in accuracy, the team 
with the minimumnumber of linesof code will win. -the team with the highestoverall score in round 2 
will  be  declared  the  winner  -participants  must  maintainfair  play  and  adhere to  event  instructions; 
cheating results in disqualification. resources: 1. 3 big classrooms with workingprojectors 2. 1 big 
classroom with workingprojector 3. prize money 12000 4. rough sheet 5. pens contact: gajendra agarwal 
- 8853030790
